alphabet.title: Alphabet
alphabet.content: Toki Pona uses nine consonants (j k l m n p s t w) and five vowels (a e i o u).

basicSentences.title: Basic Sentences
basicSentences.content:
The particle "li" separates the subject from the verb: 

soweli li moku = The cat is eating 
jan li lape = The person is sleeping 

There is no verb "to be". 
The part after "li" can also be a noun or an adjective: 

kili li moku = Fruits are food 
telo li pona = Water is good 
telo li moku = Water is a drink 

If the subject is "mi" or "sina", the "li" is always omitted: 

mi moku = I eat 
sina pona = You are good

ambiguity.title: Ambiguity
ambiguity.content:
Toki Pona has a lot of ambiguity. You'll often need to know the context to decide what things mean. For example, verbs have no tense: 

mi moku = I am eating / I was eating / I will be eating 

Many words have multiple or general meanings: 

soweli = cat / dog / (any land mammal) 
kili = (any fruit or vegetable) 

Many words can play the role of a noun, adjective, or verb: 

telo = water / wet / to wash 
pona = good, simple / to fix, to repair 

Nouns have no singular/plural, and no definite/indefinite article: 

kili = a fruit / the fruit / some fruits / the fruits

directObjects.title: Direct objects
directObjects.content:
The particle "e" separates a direct object from the rest of the sentence: 

soweli li moku e telo = The cat drinks the water 
mi telo e soweli = I'm washing the cat

modifyingWords.title: Modifying words
modifyingWords.content:
Words can be modified by appending other words: 

jan lili = small human / child 
tomo mi = my house 
pilin pona = to feel good / to be happy

negation.title: Negation
negation.content:
To negate a word, append "ala": 

mi lape ala = I'm not sleeping 
jan ala li toki = Nobody is talking

questions.title: Questions
questions.content:
To ask yes-or-no questions, replace the verb with "(verb) ala (verb)": 

sina ken ala ken lape? = Are you able to sleep? 
soweli li wile ala wile moku? = Is the cat hungry? 

Alternatively, append "anu seme" (or what) to the sentence: 

sina wile uta e mi anu seme? = Do you want to kiss me? 

To answer these questions, reply with either "(verb)" or "(verb) ala". 

To ask questions that can't be answered with yes or no, write a normal sentence and replace the word in question with "seme": 

sina moku e seme? = What are you eating? 

seme li moku e kili mi? = Who/what ate my fruit?

usingPi.title: Modifying words using "pi"
usingPi.content:
To modify an expression with a group of words, separate them with the particle "pi". It can often be thought of as "of". Note the difference: 

tomo telo nasa = crazy water house / strange bathroom 
tomo pi telo nasa = house of the crazy water / pub 

jan wawa ala = no strong people 
jan pi wawa ala = people of notstrong / weak people

usingLa.title: Providing context using "la"
usingLa.content:
To add a context to a sentence, prepend another sentence or expression, followed by "la". This often results in a structure like "If (part 1), then (part 2)" or "In the context of (part 1), (part2)." 

mi lape la ale li pona = When I'm asleep, everything is okay

time.title: Time
time.content:
You can use a "la-clause" to add a temporal context to a sentence: 

tenpo ni la mi lape = I am sleeping right now 

tenpo kama la mi lape = I will be sleeping in the future 

tenpo pini la mi lape = I slept in the past

compoundSentences.title: Compound sentences
compoundSentences.content:
Separate multiple subjects in a sentence using "en": 

lape en moku li suli = Sleep and food are important 

To say that the subject does more than one thing, you can use multiple "li-clauses": 

pipi li moku li pakala = The bug eats and destroys 

If there are several direct objects of the same verb, you can use multiple "e-clauses": 

mi moku e kili e telo = I consume fruit and water

unofficialWords.title: Unofficial words
unofficialWords.content:
Unofficial words (like names of countries, languages, or people) are capitalized and treated like adjectives. They are attached to a noun, and often simplified to Toki Pona's limited alphabet: 

mi jan Kapile = I'm Gabriele 

ma Kanata li pona lukin = Canada is pretty 

mi toki ala e toki Inli = I don't speak English 

ma tomo Nujoka li suli = New York is big

prepositions.title: Prepositions
prepositions.content:
"lon", "kepeken", "tawa", and "tan" can be used as prepositions at the end of a sentence: 

mi moku lon tomo = I eat in the house 

mi moku kepeken ilo moku = I eat using a fork 

sina pona tawa mi = You are good for me / I like you 

sina tawa weka tan seme? = Why are you leaving?

commands.title: Commands
commands.content:
To state a command, use "o" and then what you want the person to do: 

o lukin e ni! = Look at this! 

To address someone, start a sentence with "(person) o,": 

jan Malin o, sina pona lukin = Malin, you are pretty 

You can also use this together with a command, merging the two "o's": 

jan San o tawa tomo sina = Sam, go home

numbers.title: Numbers
numbers.content:
Combine number words to add them up: 

wan = 1 
tu = 2 
luka = 5 
luka luka tu wan = 13

simple_sentences.title: Simple Sentences
phrases:
You're good.
sina pona.

That's true.
ni li lon.

They are speaking.
ona li toki.

She is eating bread.
ona li moku e pan.

I know/understand.
mi sona.

Fruit is food.
kili li moku.

Everything is good.
ale li pona.

Maybe he will come.
ken la ona li kama.

Hello!
toki!

I'm going.
mi tawa.

adjectives_and_adverbs.title: Adjectives and Adverbs
phrases:
This is my house.
ni li tomo mi.

My friends are here.
jan pona mi li lon.

He speaks well.
ona li toki pona.

Small animals are cute.
soweli lili li suwi.

The new page is good.
lipu sin li pona.

That group is important.
kulupu ni li suli.

basic_particles.title: Basic Particles
phrases:
I know Toki Pona.
mi sona e toki pona.

You're watching a video.
sina lukin e sitelen tawa.

The small animal and the large animal slept well.
soweli lili en soweli suli li lape pona.

The person listens and talks.
jan li kute li toki.

Every animal needs food, water, and a shelter.
soweli ale li wile e moku e telo e tomo.

I listen to music and dance.
mi kute e kalama musi li tawa musi.

The bug ate the green plant.
pipi li moku e kasi laso.

Red, yellow, and green/blue are colors.
loje en jelo en laso li kule.

I feel the cold water and the warm air.
mi pilin e telo lete e kon seli.

Your country and my country are hot and have a lot of plants.
ma sina en ma mi li seli li jo e kasi mute.

You and me know it well.
sina en mi li sona pona e ona.

prepositions.title: Prepositions
phrases:
He's using the tool.
ona li kepeken ilo.

I am in my house.
mi lon tomo mi.

I speak using a different way.
mi toki kepeken nasin ante.

The child is eating at the store.
jan lili li moku lon esun.

You're like your father.
sina sama mama sina.

modifiers_with_pi.title: Modifiers with "pi"
phrases:
I like the Toki Pona community.
kulupu pi toki pona li pona tawa mi.

She is reading a textbook.
ona li lukin e lipu pi kama sona.

Ana's house is red.
tomo pi jan Ana li loje.

He is a good musician.
ona li jan pona pi kalama musi.

You're a very good person.
sina jan pi pona mute.

preverbs.title: Preverbs
phrases:
He is learning Toki Pona.
ona li kama sona e toki pona.

I'm still listening to them.
mi awen kute e ona.

That person can speak well.
jan ni li ken toki pona.

I'm trying to talk to her.
mi lukin toki tawa ona.

He wants to see your drawing.
ona li wile lukin e sitelen sina.

I want to become strong.
mi wile kama wawa.

I can keep watching it.
mi ken awen lukin e ona.

The bird is trying to get the bug.
waso li lukin kama jo e pipi.

questions_with_seme.title: Questions with "seme"
phrases:
What is good to you? (What do you like?)
seme li pona tawa sina?

What are you eating?
sina moku e seme?

What country are you from?
sina tan ma seme?

What's new?
seme li sin?

Where is it?
ona li lon seme?

Why do you feel bad?
sina pilin ike tan seme?

How did you learn Toki Pona?
sina kama sona e toki pona kepeken nasin seme?

Who is speaking?
jan seme li toki?

negation_and_yes_no_questions.title: Negation and yes/no questions
phrases:
I don't understand this.
mi sona ala e ni.

Nobody is talking.
jan ala li toki.

Are you good? Yes (I'm good).
sina pona ala pona? pona.

Did he read the book? No.
ona li lukin ala lukin e lipu? ala.

Is this new?
ni li sin anu seme?

Is the animal here?
soweli li lon anu seme?

vocative_and_imperative_with_o.title: Vocative and Imperative with "o"
phrases:
Hey friend, are you okay?
jan pona o, sina pona ala pona?

Sonja, you're good.
jan Sonja o, sina pona.

Read this book.
o lukin e lipu ni.

Please, hand me the tool.
o pana e ilo tawa mi.

My friend, talk to me!
jan pona mi o toki tawa mi!

Children should listen to their parents.
jan lili o kute e mama ona.

Let's go!
mi o tawa!

time.title: Time
phrases:
I understand now.
tenpo ni la mi sona.

We went to the store.
tenpo pini la mi tawa esun.

She will be away.
tenpo kama la ona li weka.

I sleep at night.
mi lape lon tenpo pimeja.

We eat during the day.
mi moku lon tenpo suno.

He wants to talk to you tomorrow.
tenpo suno kama la ona li wile toki tawa sina.

I watched the movie yesterday.
tenpo suno pini la mi lukin e sitelen tawa.

I am here today.
tenpo suno ni la mi lon.

The animal ate.
soweli li moku lon tenpo pini.

I will listen to the song later.
mi kute e kalama musi lon tenpo kama.

I'm reading a book right now.
mi lukin e lipu lon tenpo ni.

context_phrases_with_la.title: Context phrases with "la"
phrases:
In my room, I sleep.
tomo mi la mi lape.

To me, everything is fine.
mi la ale li pona.

The pictures in the book are colorful.
lipu ni la sitelen li kule.

If my pet eats, he feels good.
soweli mi li moku la ona li pilin pona.

If she's speaking, listen.
ona li toki la o kute.

According to their feelings, this is crazy.
pilin ona la ni li nasa.

You helped me. Because of this, I'll help you.
sina pana e pona tawa mi. ni la mi pana e pona tawa sina.

If you don't like that, I'll stop.
ni li ike tawa sina la mi pini.

If you don't know Toki Pona, learn!
sina sona ala sona e toki pona la o kama sona!

aboutMe.title:
Thank you for using the 
Toki Pona app!
aboutMe.content:
Hello! This is Sérgio Toledo from Brazil, I am a Software Engineer and passionate about programming. 

This free app was developed to help you learn the Toki Pona language.

tokiPona.title: What is Toki Pona?
tokiPona.content:
Toki Pona is a language created by the Canadian linguist and translator Sonja Lang and it was first published on the internet in 2001. 

It is a minimalist language, composed of only 14 phonemes (letters) and 120 words (currently, there are some other unofficial words). 

The language focuses on simple concepts and elements that are relatively universal. Inspired by Taoist philosophy, Toki Pona is not intended to be an auxiliary language, but a "yoga for the mind", aiming to express maximum meaning with minimum complexity.
